instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.820-3437B: What is 820-3437B? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP3V3_S4: What is PP3V3_S4? The "PP3V3_S4" power rail in a MacBook is used to supply 3.3 volts to certain components when the system is in the S4 power state, also known as "suspend to disk" or "hibernate." This rail is active when the MacBook is not fully off but not in an awake state, allowing for faster startup times compared to a full boot sequence. The S4 power state means Suspend to Disk: This is a low-power state where the system context is saved to disk, allowing the system to be powered down almost entirely. Upon waking, the system can restore its state from the disk, effectively resuming where it left off..
definitions.PP5V_S4RS3: What is PP5V_S4RS3? PP5V_S4RS3 is a 5v power rail present when the machine is in an S4 suspend to disk state..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.U1950: What is U1950? This chip often becomes corroded on pin 8 on the PP3V42_G3H pin causing PM_SLP_S4_L to go missing.
definitions.U6100: What is U6100? this is an SPI ROM chip that holds the BIOS which is necessary for the machine to POST or try and power on..
definitions.U7501: What is U7501? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V3_S5,  PP3V3_S3,  PP3V3_S0,  PP5V_S5,  PP5V_S4,  PP5V_S0.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
I've got this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437B</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that is not powering on. it did have very minor signs of water damage. i check around to find that i had some missing and low voltage on a few power rails.
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S4RS3</SIGNAL> 0.0
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL> 0.0
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4</SIGNAL> .041v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> .080v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> .060v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S4SW_SNS</SIGNAL> .041v

not really sure where to start from here. I think maybe and issue with <CHIP>U8050</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: sorry i should have mention those as well. <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is 8.6v and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> is 3.3v. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> is at 3.34v at <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> but no voltage at <RESISTOR>R7100</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: Where was the liquid? Is 5V pulsing on L7520? Voltage on Y1905?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: liquid damage was on <RESISTOR>R7520</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R7521</RESISTOR>,<RESISTOR>R7523</RESISTOR> as well as <RESISTOR>R8164</RESISTOR>. i check those for the correct resistance all measured good. No voltage on L7520 and y1905 pin1 is 0.003v pin2 0.0v pin3 pulsing from 0.160v to 0.189v, pin4 0.0v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: Anything happening on <RESISTOR>R7551</RESISTOR>? Check carefully it may be short pulse after start only. Checked <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area for corrosion? <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin8?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7551</RESISTOR> does spike to different voltages( tested 4 times highest 1.3v- lowest 0.028v) as soon as i plug in power. no corrosion on or around <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> even on the test points. <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin8 3.42v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
It is power cycling then. Could be caused by many things, but the usual are Corrosion in <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area, corroded pin on <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> or the clock chip. Look at the recent video Louis posted about the board from the forum. 
<CHIP>U1950</CHIP> pin 8 can have 3.4V but check under microscope for corrosion. In the video you can see the resistor and traces that usually get damaged.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
its strange for sure... i get no fan spin, no chime, no video/backlight. what i did find strange was the corrosion i did find ( with microscope) was in those 2 random places, which kinda makes me think some one either cleaned it first or the liquid didn't settle on <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> or <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> but the may have still have been damaged.

is <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> a chip i could pull off a donor to check? 

i did watch that video actually just before i started working on that board, and was extremely careful to check the resistors/traces and probe points around the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> all seem to be just fine.

so maybe i should try to change <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> and/or <CHIP>U1950</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> is fine, watch the video. <CHIP>U1950</CHIP> just needs microscope inspection of pin 8.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message:
No Title

under the microscope it looks perfect. not sure if the photo attached will be that great compared, but maybe im missing something.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: Yeah looks fine. What about the <CHIP>U6100</CHIP> area and resistors there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: You can check if 5V will come on by removing <RESISTOR>R7551</RESISTOR> and connecting EN1 to <RESISTOR>R7552</RESISTOR> (EN2). As the liquid was in that area maybe something up with <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: ok i ran a wire like you said. i do get 5.13v on <CAPACITOR>C7600</CAPACITOR> now. im guessing something is screwed with <CHIP>U7501</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-b
threads.message: No, it just proves <CHIP>U7501</CHIP> is ok put everything back like it was. I have no further clues besides you have to find the corroded part/trace. The machine is power cycling and the normal suspects look ok.
